Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of CNI-Sparing Regimens in Kidney Transplantation

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to either a CNI-sparing regimen or standard CNI-based regimen.

Participants.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) with low-to-moderate immunological risk.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a CNI-sparing regimen, while the control group received standard CNI-based therapy.

Objective.evidence: To assess the impact of CNI-sparing regimens on long-term allograft function.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was allograft function at 12 months, measured by estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was applied to outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the intervention and 100 to the control group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group showed improved eGFR (mean difference = 5.2 mL/min/1.73 mÂ², 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the intervention and 1% in the control group experiencing gastrointestinal side-effects.
